data.title: AEM Holdings (SGX:AWX) Earnings Rebound And 4.2% Margin Test Bearish Narratives
data.description:
AEM Holdings (SGX:AWX) has closed out FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of S$111.8 million and net income of S$12.9 million. Its trailing twelve month EPS sits at S$0.054 on revenue of S$399.3 million and net income of S$17.0 million. Over recent quarters the company has reported revenue of S$132.6 million in Q4 2024, S$86.0 million in Q1 2025, S$104.2 million in Q2, S$97.3 million in Q3 and S$111.8 million in Q4 2025, with quarterly net income ranging from a loss of S$0.3 million in Q2 2025 to S$12.9 million in Q4 2025. With trailing net margins at 4.2% and earnings growth considered alongside a mixed multi-year record, investors may view this set of results as an update on how sustainably the business is converting revenue into profit.

See our full analysis for AEM Holdings.

With the headline numbers on the table, the next step is to see how this earnings profile compares with the widely held narratives around AEM Holdings, and whether the recent results shift that story in a different direction.

Curious how numbers become stories that shape markets? Explore Community Narratives

Advertisement

48.2% earnings rebound versus five year slide

  • Over the last 12 months, AEM Holdings' earnings grew 48.2% with a trailing net profit margin of 4.2%, compared with 3.0% a year earlier, while the longer five year record shows average earnings contraction of 42.4% per year.
  • What stands out against a cautious, bearish angle on earnings volatility is that, even with a five year earnings decline of 42.4% per year, the latest trailing 12 month figures show S$399.3 million in revenue and S$17.0 million in net income, which
    • gives the company a positive profit base today that bears will usually watch closely when they point to that longer history of earnings contraction
    • highlights how the recent 48.2% earnings improvement and 4.2% margin sit beside that multi year decline, which is exactly the tension a cautious investor is likely to focus on.

4.2% margin on S$399.3 million sales

  • On a trailing 12 month basis to Q4 2025, AEM Holdings generated S$399.3 million of revenue and S$17.0 million of net income, which translates into a 4.2% net margin compared with 3.0% a year earlier.
  • Supporters of a more bullish narrative often point to improving profitability, and the data here shows that
    • net income on a trailing 12 month basis has risen from S$11.4 million to S$17.0 million while margin moved from 3.0% to 4.2%, which heavily supports the view that the business is converting a larger slice of sales into profit
    • quarterly figures within FY 2025 still range from a small loss of S$0.3 million in Q2 2025 to S$12.9 million in Q4 2025, reminding you that even with a higher trailing margin, short term profitability can move around from one quarter to the next.

P/E of 45.8x and DCF fair value gap

  • The shares trade on a trailing P/E of 45.8x, above the Asian semiconductor industry average of 43.8x and a peer average of 27.4x, while a DCF fair value of S$13.77 sits well above the current share price of S$2.47.
  • What is interesting for bullish investors is that the same dataset showing a premium P/E multiple also compares the S$2.47 share price with a DCF fair value of S$13.77, and that
    • frames a large gap between price and that modelled value at the same time as the market is applying a higher P/E than both industry and peer averages
    • puts more weight on whether the forecast earnings growth of about 35.9% per year and forecast revenue growth of about 14.2% per year actually arrive, because those are the inputs that typically matter most for justifying both the premium P/E and the DCF fair value.

If you want to see how other investors are turning these numbers into a broader story, have a look at Curious how numbers become stories that shape markets? Explore Community Narratives for more context around AEM Holdings' position in the semiconductor test space.

Next Steps

Don't just look at this quarter; the real story is in the long-term trend. We've done an in-depth analysis on AEM Holdings's growth and its valuation to see if today's price is a bargain. Add the company to your watchlist or portfolio now so you don't miss the next big move.

If this mix of cautious and optimistic signals leaves you on the fence, it is worth checking the numbers yourself and deciding how convincing they look to you. To see what the market currently views as the main positives in the story, take a closer look at 3 key rewards.

See What Else Is Out There

AEM Holdings' earnings story still includes a five year contraction, a thin 4.2% margin and choppy quarterly profits, even with the recent rebound.

If that mix of earnings volatility and a premium 45.8x P/E feels uncomfortable, you might prefer the steadier profile in our 326 resilient stocks with low risk scores and see how those companies line up against your risk tolerance today.

To own Mineralys Therapeutics today, you need to believe lorundrostat can translate its consistent Phase 2 and Launch-HTN data into an approved therapy for uncontrolled and resistant hypertension, with upside from chronic kidney disease and potentially OSA. The story is still binary around clinical and regulatory milestones, especially the upcoming EXPLORE-OSA and EXPLORE-CKD readouts and the planned NDA filing. data.title: Siemens Ties Nvidia Cybersecurity To Growth In Microgrids And Agriculture
data.description:
• Siemens (XTRA:SIE) has announced a new AI powered cybersecurity collaboration with Nvidia and other partners focused on industrial automation.
  • The company is also expanding its role in controlled environment agriculture and microgrid energy infrastructure.
  • These developments highlight Siemens' focus on digital security and resilient energy systems for industrial and infrastructure clients.

Siemens, trading at around ‚Ç¨248.65, sits at the intersection of industrial technology, digitalization and energy infrastructure. The stock has returned 15.1% over the past year and 115.1% over the past five years, which gives investors some context on how the market has treated XTRA:SIE through different cycles. In this context, the new AI cybersecurity and energy infrastructure initiatives add fresh angles to an already diversified business.

For investors, the collaboration with Nvidia on AI driven cybersecurity speaks directly to rising attention on operational resilience in critical infrastructure. At the same time, Siemens' work in controlled environment agriculture and microgrids ties into structural trends in energy reliability and efficient resource use. How effectively the company executes in these areas, and how clients adopt these solutions, will be key variables to watch over time.

Stay updated on the most important news stories for Siemens by adding it to your watchlist or portfolio. Alternatively, explore our Community to discover new perspectives on Siemens.

We've flagged 1 risk for Siemens. See which could impact your investment.

The Nvidia-led cybersecurity partnership puts Siemens closer to the core of AI-powered protection for industrial automation, where operational technology has historically been harder to secure than traditional IT. By embedding AI security directly into control systems, Siemens is tying its automation hardware and software more tightly to Nvidia‚Äôs data processing units and to partners like Palo Alto Networks and Forescout. For you as an investor, this points to deeper integration across the product stack and potentially stickier customer relationships, especially in sectors such as utilities, transport and advanced manufacturing. On the energy side, Siemens‚Äô presence in controlled environment agriculture and microgrids links its grid, controls and digital offerings to areas where reliability and efficiency are central buying criteria. Taken together, these moves position the company alongside peers such as Schneider Electric, ABB and GE Vernova in key areas of industrial digitalization and power resilience. The partnership approach also helps Siemens stay connected to AI and cybersecurity advances without carrying all the development risk alone.

Advertisement

How This Fits Into The Siemens Narrative

  • The AI-powered cybersecurity collaboration directly supports the narrative‚Äôs focus on industrial AI and digital automation as drivers of recurring, higher margin software and services revenue.
  • Greater reliance on partners and complex industrial AI stacks could increase execution and integration risk, which lines up with concerns in the narrative about large technology transitions weighing on profitability if rollouts are slower or more costly than expected.
  • The emphasis on controlled environment agriculture and microgrids extends Siemens‚Äô role in electrification and data center adjacent energy infrastructure, which is only partially reflected in the existing focus on hyperscaler demand and grid solutions.

Knowing what a company is worth starts with understanding its story. Check out one of the top narratives in the Simply Wall St Community for Siemens to help decide what it's worth to you.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Integrating AI-driven cybersecurity into industrial automation and coordinating with multiple partners may increase execution complexity and the risk of cost overruns on large projects.
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Expanding in microgrids and controlled environment agriculture exposes Siemens to policy, subsidy and project funding risks in newer segments, alongside existing concerns that the company has a high level of debt.
  • üéÅ The AI cybersecurity partnership and microgrid offerings aim at markets where Siemens already supplies automation, grid equipment and digital tools, which can support cross selling and longer customer relationships.
  • üéÅ Analysts highlight several strengths including value, profit and revenue growth and a reliable dividend, which provide context as Siemens targets growing markets such as industrial AI, microgrids and controlled environment agriculture.

What To Watch Going Forward

From here, you may want to track how quickly Siemens and Nvidia translate their AI cybersecurity plans into commercial deployments across factories, grids and transport systems, and whether customers adopt embedded security as standard in new automation projects. In energy infrastructure, watch for contract wins in microgrids and controlled environment agriculture, especially where Siemens can bundle power distribution, control systems and digital monitoring. It is also worth keeping an eye on how these initiatives show up in Siemens‚Äô order intake mix and whether management commentary links them to recurring software or service revenue, compared with more traditional equipment sales.

data.title: AMG Critical Materials (ENXTAM:AMG) Q4 Loss Of US$48.3 Million Challenges Bullish Earnings Narrative
data.description:
Advertisement

AMG Critical Materials FY 2025 Results Snapshot

AMG Critical Materials (ENXTAM:AMG) has just closed out FY 2025 with fourth quarter revenue of US$446.6 million and basic EPS of US$1.49 loss, setting a clear focal point for how its earnings story is developing.

Across recent periods, the company has seen quarterly revenue move from US$361.4 million and EPS of US$0.23 in Q4 2024 to US$388.1 million with EPS of US$0.16 in Q1 2025, US$439.0 million with EPS of US$0.36 in Q2, and US$434.7 million with EPS of US$0.40 in Q3, giving investors a clean run of numbers to weigh against a still pressured margin profile in the latest quarter.

See our full analysis for AMG Critical Materials.

With the headline figures on the table, the next step is to see how these results line up with the prevailing narratives around AMG Critical Materials, and where the numbers start to challenge those stories.

See what the community is saying about AMG Critical Materials

TTM still shows US$18.6 million loss

  • On a trailing twelve month basis to Q4 2025, AMG recorded total revenue of US$1.7b and a net loss of US$18.6 million, with basic EPS of US$0.58 loss.
  • What stands out against the bullish narrative is that, while bullish investors focus on forecasts of 71.31% yearly earnings growth and a return to profitability within three years, the latest TTM numbers still show losses. This means:
    • TTM net income moved from a loss of US$33.4 million in Q4 2024 to a smaller loss of US$18.6 million in Q4 2025, so the company is closer to break even but not yet there.
    • Quarterly figures inside that period swung from a US$13.1 million profit in Q3 2025 to a US$48.3 million loss in Q4 2025, which challenges the idea of a smooth path toward the bullish earnings forecasts.
On these numbers, bulls are essentially arguing that a business still reporting a TTM loss can grow into those forecasts relatively quickly, which is an optimistic read on how fast profitability can improve. üêÇ AMG Critical Materials Bull Case

US$48.3 million Q4 loss vs earlier 2025 profits

  • Within FY 2025, AMG moved from net income of US$5.0 million, US$11.5 million and US$13.1 million in Q1, Q2 and Q3 to a net loss of US$48.3 million in Q4, even as quarterly revenue stayed in a fairly tight band between US$388.1 million and US$446.6 million.
  • Bears highlight that heavy capital spending and exposure to commodity prices can hit earnings hard, and this pattern fits that cautious view because:
    • Losses over the past five years have widened at roughly 6% per year and the latest TTM period still ends in the red, which lines up with concerns about long stretches of uneven profitability.
    • Interest payments are flagged as not well covered by earnings, so a quarter like Q4 2025 with a US$48.3 million loss adds weight to worries about financial pressure if similar periods repeat.

data.title: Nebius Relies On Upfront Big Tech Contracts To Fund AI Cloud Expansion
data.description:
• Nebius Group (NasdaqGS:NBIS) is using upfront financing from large enterprise clients, including Microsoft and Meta Platforms, to reshape its financial risk profile.
  • These long-term contracts are providing greater liquidity and clearer revenue visibility for the company.
  • Nebius is expanding its data center capacity while integrating Tavily to deepen its enterprise AI cloud offering.

Nebius Group is drawing attention as it leans on customer prepayments rather than external capital to support growth, while trading at a share price of $106.12. The stock has returned 4.2% over the past week, 16.0% over the past month, 18.0% year to date, and 194.9% over the past year, which puts recent business moves under a brighter spotlight for investors watching NasdaqGS:NBIS.

For investors, the shift toward upfront financing and long-term contracts with large enterprises, combined with heavier investment in data center capacity and AI capabilities through the Tavily acquisition, directly affects how Nebius Group's risk profile may be viewed. These changes relate to funding needs, revenue visibility, and the company‚Äôs role in AI cloud infrastructure, and are likely to remain key points to monitor around NasdaqGS:NBIS.

Nebius Group‚Äôs decision to lean on upfront payments from large customers like Microsoft and Meta Platforms shifts part of the financing burden from lenders and equity markets to its own client base. For you as an investor, that means liquidity is tied more closely to contract execution and less to capital market conditions. Long dated agreements and customer prepayments can smooth cash inflows and give clearer visibility over future revenue, but they also concentrate exposure in a small group of hyperscale clients. The aggressive data center build out and the Tavily acquisition indicate that Nebius is trying to move up the stack from pure infrastructure into more software rich, enterprise grade AI cloud services, putting it in more direct competition with Amazon, Alphabet and other cloud providers. That can support pricing power if the platform resonates with developers, yet it raises execution risk around integration, uptime and ongoing capital intensity in an already crowded AI-infrastructure space.

How This Fits Into The Nebius Group Narrative

  • The use of upfront customer financing and large multi year contracts directly supports the narrative that Nebius can use partnerships and strong funding access to build recurring revenue around AI focused infrastructure.
  • Heavy reliance on a few very large deals ties into the narrative concern that customer concentration and sector consolidation could make it harder for Nebius to secure diversified, long term earnings streams.
  • The Tavily acquisition and push into full stack AI services adds a software and data layer that is not fully captured in earlier commentary that focused mainly on GPU infrastructure and capacity expansion.

Knowing what a company is worth starts with understanding its story. Check out one of the top narratives in the Simply Wall St Community for Nebius Group to help decide what it's worth to you.

The Risks and Rewards Investors Should Consider

  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Dependence on a small number of very large contracts with companies like Microsoft and Meta Platforms increases the impact if any single customer changes strategy or scales back usage.
  • üéÅ Long term, prepaid agreements with major enterprises can support more predictable cash flows and give management flexibility over how to fund expansion.
  • üéÅ Expansion of capacity and the addition of Tavily‚Äôs AI search capabilities position Nebius to offer full stack solutions that could appeal to AI developers looking beyond established providers such as Amazon and Alphabet.

What To Watch Going Forward

From here, it is worth tracking how quickly Nebius converts its contracted backlog into active, revenue producing capacity, and whether new sites come online on the timelines management has outlined. Keep an eye on any updates to the terms or scale of the Microsoft and Meta Platforms agreements, as well as customer diversification beyond these anchor clients. Integration of Tavily into the broader platform, and customer uptake of higher value AI software services versus pure compute, will also help indicate whether Nebius can build a defensible position against larger cloud peers.

data.description:
Singapore Land Group (SGX:U06) has reported its FY 2025 first half numbers with revenue of S$372.2 million and net income of S$111.4 million, translating to basic EPS of S$0.078. The company has seen revenue move from S$354.6 million in 1H FY 2024 to S$372.2 million in 1H FY 2025, while EPS shifted from S$0.072 to S$0.078 over the same periods, which allows investors to consider solid top line scale alongside signs of margin pressure.

Margins Slip From 38% To 34.8%

  • Over the last 12 months, net profit margin was 34.8%, compared with 38% in the prior year, while trailing 12 month net income was S$272.3 million on S$783.1 million of revenue.
  • What stands out for a more cautious, bearish view is that this margin compression sits alongside a 1% per year earnings decline over five years, which raises questions about profit resilience even though 1H FY 2025 net income of S$111.4 million is above the S$103.7 million recorded in 1H FY 2024.
    • Bears point to the drop from 38% to 34.8% net margin as evidence that profitability per dollar of revenue has been under pressure across the last two years of data.
    • They also highlight that trailing 12 month net income of S$272.3 million is lower than the S$291.9 million level reported in the earlier trailing set, which lines up with the longer run 1% annual earnings decline.
On top of this compression in margins, skeptics may argue that recent profit levels still need to prove they can hold up if revenue conditions become less supportive. üêª Singapore Land Group Bear Case

Five Year Earnings Trend Points To 1% Decline

  • The analysis flags that reported earnings have declined at an average rate of 1% per year over the past five years, even though 1H FY 2025 basic EPS of S$0.078 is slightly above the S$0.072 recorded in 1H FY 2024.
  • Supporters of a more optimistic, bullish angle often focus on the fact that trailing 12 month EPS of about S$0.204 is higher than the S$0.198 level observed in the earlier trailing period. However, this shorter term improvement sits against that 1% five year earnings decline, so the recent lift does not fully counter the longer term drift.
    • Backers of the bullish angle may point to revenue trending from S$354.6 million in 1H FY 2024 to S$372.2 million in 1H FY 2025, and from S$748.6 million to S$783.1 million on a trailing basis, as a sign that the business is still scaling.
    • At the same time, the five year 1% earnings decline signal means any bullish case has to show how current profitability can be maintained or improved rather than assuming past patterns will simply reverse.

P/E Of 18.9x Sits Between Peers And DCF Value

  • Investors weighing a bullish angle on valuation often see the discount to the 23.1x peer P/E as supportive. Yet that is balanced by two constraints, the slight premium to the 18.7x industry average and the fact that the current S$3.59 share price is higher than the S$3.47 DCF fair value, which together argue for careful attention to how future profit metrics evolve.
    • Supporters of the bullish view can argue that an 18.9x P/E with a peer discount leaves some room if earnings stabilise relative to the 1% five year decline, but that argument depends heavily on how margins and net income trend from here.
    • Others will focus more on the S$0.204 trailing 12 month EPS and the P/E implied at S$3.59, viewing the gap to DCF fair value as a reason to be measured when judging how much of the current earnings profile is already priced in.

Margins Ease From 9.3% To 8.6%

  • Bears point to this margin slip as a sign that rising costs and mix are biting, yet the consensus narrative also highlights long term drivers such as Pro services and higher ticket projects:

  • On a trailing 12 month basis, same store sales moved from a 1.8% decline a year ago to 0.3% growth now, with quarterly prints ranging from a 0.3% decline in Q1 FY 2026 to 1% growth in Q2 and 0.4% growth in Q4.
  • Consensus narrative talks about pent up demand for renovations and aging housing stock supporting long term activity, and the recent same store sales trend gives a mixed read on that bullish view:
